## Depictions

See also: [Replicas of the Statue of
Liberty](/wiki/Replicas_of_the_Statue_of_Liberty "Replicas of the Statue of
Liberty") and [Statue of Liberty in popular
culture](/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty_in_popular_culture "Statue of Liberty in
popular culture")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Las_Vegas_NY_NY_Hotel.jpg/260px-
Las_Vegas_NY_NY_Hotel.jpg)](/wiki/File:Las_Vegas_NY_NY_Hotel.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Las_Vegas_NY_NY_Hotel.jpg "Enlarge")

A replica of the Statue of Liberty forms part of the exterior decor at the
[New York-New York Hotel and Casino](/wiki/New_York-New_York_Hotel_and_Casino
"New York-New York Hotel and Casino") on the [Las Vegas
Strip](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip "Las Vegas Strip")

Hundreds of [replicas of the Statue of
Liberty](/wiki/Replicas_of_the_Statue_of_Liberty "Replicas of the Statue of
Liberty") are displayed worldwide.[172] A smaller version of the statue, one-
fourth the height of the original, was given by the American community in
Paris to that city. It now stands on the [Île aux
Cygnes](/wiki/%C3%8Ele_aux_Cygnes "Île aux Cygnes"), facing west toward her
larger sister.[172] A replica 30 feet (9.1 m) tall stood atop the Liberty
Warehouse on West 64th Street in Manhattan for many years;[172] it now resides
at the [Brooklyn Museum](/wiki/Brooklyn_Museum "Brooklyn Museum").[173] In a
patriotic tribute, the [Boy Scouts of America](/wiki/Boy_Scouts_of_America
"Boy Scouts of America"), as part of their [Strengthen the Arm of
Liberty](/wiki/Strengthen_the_Arm_of_Liberty "Strengthen the Arm of Liberty")
campaign in 1949–1952, donated about two hundred replicas of the statue, made
of stamped copper and 100 inches (2,500 mm) in height, to states and
municipalities across the United States.[174] Though not a true replica, the
statue known as the [Goddess of Democracy](/wiki/Goddess_of_Democracy "Goddess
of Democracy") temporarily erected during the [Tiananmen Square protests of
1989](/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989 "Tiananmen Square protests of
1989") was similarly inspired by French democratic traditions—the sculptors
took care to avoid a direct imitation of the Statue of Liberty.[175] Among
other recreations of New York City structures, a replica of the statue is part
of the exterior of the [New York-New York Hotel and Casino](/wiki/New_York-
New_York_Hotel_and_Casino "New York-New York Hotel and Casino") in Las
Vegas.[176]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Liberty_issue_17c_1971.JPG/170px-
Liberty_issue_17c_1971.JPG)](/wiki/File:Liberty_issue_17c_1971.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Liberty_issue_17c_1971.JPG "Enlarge")

Head of Liberty, U.S. airmail stamp, 1971 issue

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/LineartPresRev.png/170px-
LineartPresRev.png)](/wiki/File:LineartPresRev.png)

[](/wiki/File:LineartPresRev.png "Enlarge")

[Reverse](/wiki/Reverse_\(coin\) "Reverse \(coin\)") side of a [Presidential
Dollar coin](/wiki/Presidential_$1_Coin_Program "Presidential $1 Coin
Program")

As an American icon, the Statue of Liberty has been depicted on the country's
coinage and stamps. It appeared on commemorative coins issued to mark its 1986
centennial, and on New York's 2001 entry in the [state
quarters](/wiki/State_quarters "State quarters") series.[177] An image of the
statue was chosen for the [American Eagle platinum bullion
coins](/wiki/American_Platinum_Eagle "American Platinum Eagle") in 1997, and
it was placed on the [reverse](/wiki/Reverse_\(coin\) "Reverse \(coin\)"), or
tails, side of the [Presidential Dollar
series](/wiki/Presidential_$1_Coin_Program "Presidential $1 Coin Program") of
circulating coins.[26] Two images of the statue's torch appear on the current
[ten-dollar bill](/wiki/United_States_ten-dollar_bill "United States ten-
dollar bill").[178] The statue's intended photographic depiction on a 2010
[forever stamp](/wiki/Forever_stamp "Forever stamp") proved instead to be of
the replica at the Las Vegas casino.[179]

Depictions of the statue have been used by many regional institutions. Between
1986[180] and 2000,[181] New York State issued [license
plates](/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plates_of_New_York "Vehicle registration
plates of New York") with an outline of the statue to either the front or the
side of the serial number.[180][181] The [Women's National Basketball
Association](/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association "Women's National
Basketball Association")'s [New York Liberty](/wiki/New_York_Liberty "New York
Liberty") use both the statue's name and its image in their logo, in which the
torch's flame doubles as a basketball.[182] The [New York
Rangers](/wiki/New_York_Rangers "New York Rangers") of the [National Hockey
League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") depicted the
statue's head on their [third jersey](/wiki/Third_jersey "Third jersey"),
beginning in 1997.[183] The [National Collegiate Athletic
Association](/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association "National
Collegiate Athletic Association")'s [1996 Men's Basketball Final
Four](/wiki/1996_NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Tournament "1996 NCAA
Men's Division I Basketball Tournament"), played at New Jersey's [Meadowlands
Sports Complex](/wiki/Meadowlands_Sports_Complex "Meadowlands Sports
Complex"), featured the statue in its logo.[184] The [Libertarian Party of the
United States](/wiki/Libertarian_Party_of_the_United_States "Libertarian Party
of the United States") uses the statue in its emblem.[185]

The statue is a frequent subject in popular culture. In music, it has been
evoked to indicate support for American policies, as in [Toby
Keith](/wiki/Toby_Keith "Toby Keith")'s song "[Courtesy of the Red, White and
Blue (The Angry
American)](/wiki/Courtesy_of_the_Red,_White_and_Blue_\(The_Angry_American\)
"Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue \(The Angry American\)")", and in
opposition, appearing on the cover of the [Dead Kennedys](/wiki/Dead_Kennedys
"Dead Kennedys")' album _[Bedtime for Democracy](/wiki/Bedtime_for_Democracy
"Bedtime for Democracy")_ , which protested the Reagan administration.[186] In
film, the torch is the setting for the climax of director [Alfred
Hitchcock](/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock "Alfred Hitchcock")'s 1942 movie
_[Saboteur](/wiki/Saboteur_\(film\) "Saboteur \(film\)")_.[187] The statue
makes one of its most famous cinematic appearances in the 1968 picture
_[Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(1968_film\) "Planet of the
Apes \(1968 film\)")_ , in which it is seen half-buried in sand.[186][188] It
is knocked over in the science-fiction film _[Independence
Day](/wiki/Independence_Day_\(1996_film\) "Independence Day \(1996 film\)")_
[189] and in _[Cloverfield](/wiki/Cloverfield "Cloverfield")_ the head is
ripped off.[190] In [Jack Finney](/wiki/Jack_Finney "Jack Finney")'s time-
travel novel _[Time and Again](/wiki/Time_and_Again_\(novel\) "Time and Again
\(novel\)")_ , the right arm of the statue, on display in the early 1880s in
Madison Square Park, plays a crucial role.[191] [Robert
Holdstock](/wiki/Robert_Holdstock "Robert Holdstock"), consulting editor of
_[The Encyclopedia of Science
Fiction](/wiki/The_Encyclopedia_of_Science_Fiction "The Encyclopedia of
Science Fiction")_ , wondered in 1979,

> Where would science fiction be without the Statue of Liberty? For decades it
> has towered or crumbled above the wastelands of deserted [E]arth—giants have
> uprooted it, aliens have found it curious ... the symbol of Liberty, of
> optimism, has become a symbol of science fiction's pessimistic view of the
> future.[192]
